Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: About 2 hours per week outside class.
6-8 hours
anywhere from 2-15
6-8 hr, including lecture, TF time, practice questions, reading.
2 normally, 6 during exam weeks
Around 3-4 hours
10 hours
5 hours
3hrs

10 on quiz/exam weeks
3-4 on normal weeks
5 hours
6 hours
Overall, I learned a lot from this course. I think having a brand new instructor who is a post-doc teach the course was rough at first. Please see comments below on Question 7.

Useful information, would have been better to just teach it as micro economics, and did not try and stretch it to fit healthcare, which sometimes made it more confusing.  The in class activities were mostly ineffective teaching methods, but I appreciated the attempt.  In particular the consulting firm and bidding games were kind of a waste of time.

The professor was inexperienced and unclear on many of the topics. The exams and quizzes were not clear and did not reflect knowledge base. The TA sections were excellent, however, this is an important foundational course and needs to be taught by someone more experienced.

The course was very challenging and discussion sections were very conducive to my personal learning. Some in-class activities were less helpful, and this may have been due in part to the time constraints. The last few lectures were very enjoyable, because the class became more health-centric after we were able to apply our learned concepts.

Microeconomics for health policy is a very dense, quantitative subject and unfortunately the course wasn't taught in the most clear and cogent manner. Lecture was very disorganized and many students relied on office hours for clarity.

I learned a lot!! the material was presented in a clear, logical manner, and lectures largely were incredibly helpful. When there were gaps in my knowledge, section was a blessing and made such a difference. I really do feel like I much better understand economics now! Would suggest changing the last 2 weeks of class---I didn't learn much from the consulting exercise (felt very fake and cursory and not in-depth enough) or from the last week's discussion of the paper. Would prefer to have 2 additional lectures worth of material to learn.
The course moved really fast, and it was often hard to relate each topic to the next.
There is quite a bit of material covered in one session; perhaps splitting into two classes per week would be more conducive to understanding.
Good materials overall, but more healthcare related contents would be better.

Overall great course for anyone with little to no exposure to microeconomics. The second half of the semester I found to be most beneficial for health policy and healthcare management students, as it really connected themes we were learning about in other courses to much larger economic issues.
decent class for microecon. Not too hard material and just the right speed/pace

The course wasn't too tough, but I think that it would be better if the TA sessions every week were actually a part of the course because they are helpful, but given the unknown scheduling during enrollment were difficult to attend sometimes.
The power points can be clearer

very interesting material, but I was frustrated that we were not given feedback on exams and quizzes. It made it incredibly challenging to learn from these evaluations considering we were not made aware what where we went wrong.

strength: a very good introduction course for microeconomics, even for someone who has not taken a maths module in the past 4 years. the topics are closely related to health care thus may have good application in our future career. 

weakness: the lesson occasionally goes a little fast

Strengths:section
Weaknesses: didn't always get much out of lecture

Strengths:I like economics, so overall I enjoyed the course. Dr. Carattini did try to engage us with the consulting activity, videos, etc.

Weaknesses: There was little application to health care. The exams and quizzes were too long and repetitive.
Good intro course

Strengths:

- TA (Kayla) was exceptionally good at coming at content from a different angle to help make it accessible

- Problem sets worked well (maybe just make them mandatory for 10% of final grade or something?)

- Good coverage of basic concepts, well ramped

- Liked it actually addressed health-related concerns

Weaknesses:

- Stefano started off weak, but got much better through the runtime of the course

- Confusion over how participation grade was calculated, this didn't bother me but was frequently bemoaned by peers

- Course content could've been better integrated
Course was too fast paced for most people as evident by grade distributions

Strengths: The TFs were approachable and knowledgeable; homework was well-written and, I felt, where I really learned the material. 

Weaknesses: Lecture was poorly conducted, often resulting in the professor spending far too long answering individuals' questions and, hence, being forced to push through complicated topics (elasticity, nash equilibriums) in what little time remained; the miderm/final were far too long and failed to push students to engage with the material in a more nuanced, meaningful way; the consulting exercise was a colossal waste of time; other than the homework and lecture on Arrow's paper, this course had almost nothing to do with health care.

This is surprisingly the first time I have ever taken economics throughout the entire academic career, and I genuinely enjoyed it. As a Health Policy student, Microecon was incredibly helpful towards my understanding of public health initiatives.

Very interesting material, especially towards the later portion of the course when the relevance to the health care field became more apparent. The beginning of the semester was more challenging, particularly because the exams were very different than the material learned in lecture (much more math/calculations on the exams, and much more theoretical in lecture).
There was a greater emphasis on micro economics in general, rather than for health care professionals. There was only a total of 3 weeks of material on health care economics.

I quite liked the subject and the course overall. Since there was a lot of material, I found that it was almost necessary to read the textbook ahead of the lectures. The discussion sections were also very helpful to digest the material.
The course content and material is both interesting and useful when applying to the real world.
The lecture material often did not match up with the homework material. I actually found section to be most helpful.
Very good intro course into healthcare economics
The teacher lacked any sensitivity towards students and was quite crass. He wasnt flexible and didnt explain a lot of concepts, leaving students to learn from YouTube at times.

Strengths: realized how essential economics is to health care and public health
weaknesses: this realization was not made until the end, the majority of the course was not tied to public health

The class was good, definitely stronger at the end with primary papers by Akerloff, Spence, and Arrow.

I think the class could be strengthened by further integrating the mathematical aspects of microeconomics.

Stefano did move quickly during class, but he only had less than 2 hours face time with us so it was not his fault.  I did attend section and his office hours, which also helped a lot.  It seemed most did not take advantage of his office hours.  I would have been nice to have met twice a week instead of once.

I think Stefano could have done a better job aligning his lectures to Abbey's material.  There were some disconnects apparent in themes and I felt I might not be learning what is most important for *public health* microecon as opposed to *generally* in microecon.  Sometimes the slides were unclear as well, and I felt like Abbey might have had something specific she said every year at that slide, but since we weren't hearing it it made less sense.
Overall, the homework practice helped me to understand the concepts a lot and hammered home the material.

This is a difficult course for those who have never encountered economics. The key strengths are in the organization of the slides, as well as the brilliant instruction provided by the teaching assistants. In addition, Stefano was always available when needed, and provided fantastic instruction one-on-one. 

Having never studied economics, I found the pace of the lectures a little fast and struggled to keep up. This was soon remedied when I began attending the TA sessions - these are an invaluable adjunct that will lead to a rapid comprehension of sometimes abstruse information.
It was a good introduction to microeconomics, but it would have been helpful to have each concept tied back to healthcare related topics.

Course content is good. Its a very intro based class.
Maybe meeting for three hours a week as a class, instead of 1.5 hours, would allow us to cover more content! At least we can do macro economics too!

The testing model was a little unfair. After being told that our 30 minute  quiz would cover a couple of weeks, we were surprised the week before when the professor told us it would act as yet another midterm.
Very bad course overall. It was disorganized, and students were constantly confused as to what was going on.
great instructor, simplifies concepts.

Stefano was responsive when we had questions. However, he was not the best instructor in his teaching style as well as the way he treated the class sometimes. For example, sometimes he seemed condescending in the way he treated students/the class in general.
I appreciated the effort, sometimes had difficultly explaining concepts.

The professor was inexperienced and unclear on many of the topics. The exams and quizzes were not clear and did not reflect knowledge base. The TA sections were excellent, however, this is an important foundational course and needs to be taught by someone more experienced.

Once Stefano got into the rhythm of things, his lectures were clear. His enthusiasm for making sure we have learned the material (and his enthusiasm for providing the tools to help us succeed in the course) was conducive to my learning, and I was glad he made himself very available for office hours.
Solid. Clearly really cared about the class. Sometimes was a bit too slow or didn't make a ton of sense, but 80% of the time it was good.

The professor was very smart and did care about his students doing well, but I think he expected many students to come in with a basic understanding with economics and that was not the case. He moved much faster than the class was comfortable with.

Strengths: Receptive to students' suggestions, was accessible in open office hours

To improve: Better time management may add to course's flow and ease of understanding; 

I recommend highlighting main points of a concept to make it clearer to the student the context. Also, allocating more time to the math and numeric portions of problems and concepts that will be tested and less time for more abstract concepts that will be iterated again later when the math is done. 

Activities were somewhat helpful but took a lot of time away from teaching time, and sometimes math and concepts were left out to revise on students' own.
Tried his best to accommodate students.

Stefano was clearly very knowledgeable about economics and actively tried to stimulate student interest in the content he presented. The only thing I would suggest improving, is that because he is an expert in the field of economics, it was sometimes difficult to understand things he'd explain because his knowledge base was significantly greater than our own. I fear he sometimes assumed the audience knew much more than we did, and as a result we were sometimes confused when he described things a certain way or when answering questions.
Very direct professor and not willing to sugarcoat things, which is a good thing. Although, maybe can be a bit more sensitive in terms of being able to listen to other students.
Was fine but could have been more organized

I really liked the material of this course, but I would say that for the most time, it was challenging to communicate with Stefano. He would take questions in class, but would not answer them and would talk about things unrelated. There was also an instance in which a student asked a question and he falsely assumed that that student was the only one with that question and did not answer it. He rejected this question in a manner that came off as quite rude.

Stefano has shown great effort to make this course interesting and provided many interactions with us. There were fun group work during the classes and it is a better learning journey than simply listening to the lecturer. the extra quiz also provided us opportunity to learn what we have misunderstood during the first half of the semester.
Teaching may be improved by being a bit more clear with explanations

Dr. Carattini would visibly get frustrated with us at times, but ofteb that was due to him not staying on track time wise. He also expressed disappointment over our performance on the consulting activity, but we had little time to prepare and our panelists enjoyed our presentations. In addition, he designed exams and especially quizzes that were too long which did not seem to serve a true purpose. There were ways to design an equally challenging and less confusing shorter exam. 

I do understand this was his first time teaching this course and any course at YSPH. With that said, he did a pretty good job, but his Teaching Fellows definitely made up in the areas where he lacked.

I think that he got much better as the course went on, from a fairly low initial base to quite a competent and articulate professor. I would merely advise he skips the first stage in future. Overall, I think while I would give him a solid tick of approval (accounting that this is his first time teaching) but hope he incorporates his experience into future classes (as he did within this course).

Expert in the field, very knowledgeable
Has trouble explaining things to student/ reading students confusion.

I like Professor Stefano. I feel that he's an extremely intelligent person who struggled in the larger lecture settings. In small-class settings, conversely, Stefano is very, very good at working through and explaining complex topics. 

My main issue though is not with Professor Stefano but with the department/school. A solid understanding of economics, as far as I understand, is integral to health policy/management work. The HPM department, at least, consists of a number economists by training, economists who now work actively in health or health care. The class of 2019 is the largest cohort to come through YSPH perhaps ever. So why, for this large class, for such a fundamental subject, did the administration ultimately decide to task a non-departmental, non-health care affiliated professor with this course? I understand that Professor Friedman is on maternity leave; I understand that staffing is complex and that, perhaps, this was the best use of available resources. Still, it does make me wonder about how much the departmental faculty here cares about me and my education.

Pretty good for an opt-in professor--incredibly intelligent, and easy to follow during lectures. I appreciated the opportunities for allowing students to apply the material during lectures through exercises during class. Says "very good" a lot.

At the beginning of the semester, lectures moved a bit too quickly, and students often felt intimidated approaching Stefano to ask questions. He became more approachable over the course of the semester though, and frequently sought feedback to improve his teaching. His accent was a bit difficult to understand at times, but he tried his best and was very willing to repeat things if necessary.
Stefano did a great job for a first time professor.
Stefano was a great instructor to cover such a dense material in a relatively short amount of time. He was really great about listening to the students feedback and being available.

I understand Professor Stefano was a substitute for this course. However, I was disappointed with his teaching style. During class he sometimes spent a large amount of time on a topic that was not important or part of the course content, and then breezed over the material that was more complex and needed more explanation. He often times did not answer students' questions directly and on more than one occasion made errors when trying to teach content on the board to students during lecture.
Very sharp! Always great when asked questions.
The teacher lacked any sensitivity towards students and was quite crass. He wasnt flexible and didnt explain a lot of concepts, leaving students to learn from YouTube at times.

strengths: very knowledgeable, passionate about topic
weaknesses: sometimes struggled translating knowledge to students
Professor Carattini is passionate about economics and a rich resource. I found that he was especially helpful in his office hours.

Stefano is a very bight guy, and it was his first time teaching this course.  I have nothing to compare it to, but I did take away a lot of information which I did not know prior to taking this class.  I learned a lot about econ, and thought he did a great job.

I think a lot of students were frustrated by the fact that they didn't absorb everything immediately upon going to lecture and without reading the material.  I think this was an immature assumption to make, but all of my undergrad was like that, so I expected courses here to be like that too.  I do not think that was a problem with the instructor, I think that is the nature of grad school--it is harder and goes faster.  I definitely learned a lot of things from Stefano, and given this was his first course, I think he did a good job with room for improvement as all instructors have.
The improvement would come from stressing more of what Abbey's slides stress and being clearer at the beginning about expectations.  I think it was good when Stefano told us to read the book *before* coming to class, but maybe it would have helped to say that at the beginning of the year.  I did not always read the book before class, but knowing that it was expected and that what the audience the lecture was built for made me more comfortable not understanding the material completely upon leaving the classroom.  I knew I had more work to do on it.

Stefano is clearly a brilliant academic but was tasked with teaching a course at the last minute. There appeared to be an assumption of prior knowledge, which made initially grasping the lectures difficult. 

Stefano was quick to respond to feedback, however, and readily answered questions in class, as well as outside of class. 

I learned a lot by sitting for 45 minutes with him - a cloud was lifted and it made sense. His grasp of the subject cannot be underestimated. 

I highly recommend attending the personal teaching sessions with Stefano as well as the office hours from the beginning. This can be a difficult subject to catch up on if you fall behind!

Stefano wants to see students succeed and is available to help students with specific questions they may have during office hours.
It would help if the instructor paced each class session based on feedback from students and reiterate topics when students have specific questions.
I enjoyed Stefanos class. He was well prepared and always full of energy. You saw his passion right through.

Professor Carattini clearly cared a lot about the students and put a lot of thought into making the course fair. That being said, he wasn't a clear lecturer and  I got a lot more out of reading the textbook than going to lectures.

This professor had few strengths and many weaknesses. He was a poor lecturer and even worse exam-writer. Grading was very slow and disorganized, with frequent wild miscalculations and curve-swings (followed by a failed extra credit experiment hoping to make things better).
I would take this course if you are interested in the field, especially if the original professor is teaching the course.
good basic information
Important foundational course that would be solid with an experienced professor.
You will learn a lot! Fine teacher w/ very important material. Definitely would recommend strongly. This information is vital to know if you want to work in health policy.

I felt that this course was heavily focused on self-learning, as class was 2 hours per week with a lot of material to cover. I found myself relying heavily on the readings and less on the lectures because they were covered more clearly and with continuity. 

I would recommend to a student with some time to comb through readings. Materials were a good intro to microeconomics.
Great intro course for anyone looking to learn about microeconomics, but also how economic factors affect the U.S health care system and insurance policies.
interesting material and I would suggest taking it as well as taking advantage of the TFs
Even if this is not a requirement for students outside HP and HCM. If you want to work in the industry, this is very helpful to learn how the market works.
You may have to supplement your learning with outside studying from sources like YouTube, section, etc.
It is an intensive microeconomics course, but it is not actually related to health care professionals. Occasionally, we would have pharmaceutical companies as our examples in problems.

This course will provide for you the basic tools needed to see the health care industry through an economic lens. if you have taken an econ course before however you may want to explore waiver options.
I highly recommend this course for anyone interested in the business, policy, or strategy sides of public health/health care.

This course provides a great foundation of microeconomics, particularly in the health care field. It emphasized the structure of perfect markets, and how there are many market failures that make health care so complex.
This is an interesting and useful course. However, I felt the content was not taught effectively or in a clear way.
Regular economics but much more interesting as it is applied to health care.
An introduction to Microeconomics for health care professionals.

I would highly recommend this course to others in the healthcare field.  It could have been a little more healthcare related, but I understand the basics have to be understood before branching out.  I would like to take another course on Healthcare and environmental economics.

This is a microeconomics speed round.  It moves very fast and there are a lot of details that you have to know and understand.  You will gain a lot of knowledge from this course, and be able to think critically about health care in a whole new way.  Be prepared to do extra work outside of class because of this.

This is a difficult course for those who have never come across economic concepts. Economics is a fascinating and strangely beautiful subject that requires patience to fully internalise its concepts.

To avoid these possible difficulties, I would advise attending office hours from the beginning and reaching out to Profs/lecturers sooner rather than later when stumped. 

Good luck and enjoy.

This course is ideal for students with no background in economics or business.  The course goes in depth on basic microeconomics concepts to set a framework for students' understanding of the healthcare system.
Its a standard intro Econ course .. not overwhelming and its interesting
I would not recommend this course to anyone, ever.
